instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS? This is PPBUS_G3H after passing through a current sense resistor that splits it off from the rest of PPBUS_G3H. The purpose of this is so that we can measure how much current is flowing to this part of the machine..
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS</SIGNAL> short
threads.message:
No liquid. Not a popped cap.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 8.6V

First noticed S5 rails were 0.5V.
Checked EN 3v3 and 5V S5 all fine.
Tried <TRANSISTOR>Q7520</TRANSISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7560</TRANSISTOR> and <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> That's when I notice <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISN</SIGNAL> is shorted to ground. No visible signs of bad caps.
Plugged it up to PSU 8V @3A and nothing is burning my finger. No caps, nothing.

Ideas please?

threads.title: [SOLVED] <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS</SIGNAL> short
threads.message:
<CAPACITOR>C7621</CAPACITOR> got slightly warm at about 4A. Removed, short gone.
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISN</SIGNAL> now .7V

Doh! Dumb mother fucker! [SIZE=14px][B]Fuse[/B][/SIZE]... Oh geez
